snippet: Questions have been raised about the role of family wealth in the sentencing of a 16-year-old behind the wheel in an accident that killed four people in North Texas.
abstract: Families in Fort Worth of victims killed or injured by 16-year-old Ethan Couch are outraged after juvenile court Judge Jean Boyd sentences him to 10 years' probation in rehabilitation facility; prosecutors, who sought sentence of 20 years in prison, say they have never heard of a case where the defense blamed a person's conduct on the parents' wealth, or 'affluenza,' as psychologist for defense called it.

byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and JOHN SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez reported from Houston, and John Schwartz from New York.

lead_paragraph: Questions have been raised about the role of family wealth in the sentencing of a 16-year-old behind the wheel in an accident that killed four people in North Texas.

headline.main: Teenager’s Sentence in Fatal Drunken-Driving Case Stirs ‘Affluenza’ Debate
headline.print_headline: Teenager’s Sentence in Fatal Drunken-Driving Case Stirs ‘Affluenza’ Debate
